params.note: Protocol describes a method for generating striatal neural rosette (SNR)-derived brain organoids with predictable organization and reproducible cellular composition, mimicking neural tube development.
Key modifications include: (1) use of vitamin A-containing B27 supplement, (2) no Wnt inhibitors, (3) prolonged early treatment with FGF2 and EGF, (4) late transient exposure to trophic factors.
Compared to other methods, this protocol avoids mechanical dissection from NR clusters and uses FGF2/EGF treatment and MG embedding to promote neural progenitor proliferation.
1-month-old SNR-derived organoids contain telencephalic neural progenitors, inhibitory and excitatory neurons, with reproducible cell composition confirmed by scRNA-seq.
Computational lineage tracing identified signaling pathways associated with excitatory and inhibitory neural lineage specification from unspecified progenitors.

5-month-old organoids contain diverse neural cells: excitatory/inhibitory progenitors, deep/superficial cortical neurons, LGE-derived interneurons, striatal inhibitory neurons, astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, periendothelial and ependymal cells.
Ependymal cells line the lumen; cortical neurons exhibit lamination; striatal neurons are distributed beneath cortical layers.
5-month-old organoids contain functionally mature neurons that generate action potentials, receive synaptic inputs, and form functional neural networks.
The SNR-based approach can be adapted to generate other brain region-specific organoids (striatal, thalamic, cerebellar, midbrain) for studying inter-regional communication and connectivity.
Organoids with predictable organization and reproducible composition may be useful for biocomputing and artificial intelligence applications.
Limitations include manual SNR isolation, heterogeneity in SNR size, shape, and quality, contributing to organoid-to-organoid variability.
Manual SNR isolation requires time and technical skill.
